content: The Act titled "National Uniformity for Food Act of 1998" aims to establish national uniformity for food regulations. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 1998 aims to establish national uniformity for food regulations by amending sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to ensure consistency in labeling and safety requirements for food products. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 1998 seeks to establish consistency in food regulations by amending sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, including redesignating sections 403B and 403C as 403C and 403D, and inserting a new section after 403A. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 1998 aims to establish consistency in food regulations by amending sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, including the addition of a new section on uniformity in food safety warning notification requirements. The National Uniformity for Food Act of 1998 prohibits states from implementing their own food safety warning notification requirements unless they are identical to those prescribed under the Act. The Act defines the dissemination of information about food and what constitutes a warning regarding food safety hazards. States can petition the Secretary for exemptions from certain requirements. The Secretary may grant exemptions to states for food safety warning notification requirements if they protect public interest, do not violate federal laws, and do not overly burden interstate commerce. States can petition the Secretary for national standards through a regulatory process. States can petition the Secretary for national standards through a regulatory process, which includes public comment periods and specific timeframes for action on the petitions. During the 60-day period, the Secretary must inform the petitioner in writing of the reasons for not taking action, the expected action date, and the likely action. The Secretary must take action on the petition within 120 days after the public comment period. Failure to comply with this requirement constitutes final agency action subject to judicial review. If non-compliance is found, the court can order the Secretary to comply within a specified timeframe. A State may establish a requirement that would otherwise violate certain sections if needed to address an imminent hazard to health, with conditions including informing the Secretary and submitting a petition for an exemption or national standard. The Secretary must act on any petition submitted within 7 days. Failure to comply constitutes final agency action for judicial review, with the court able to order compliance within an appropriate timeframe. The court must approve actions under this section. It does not affect product liability laws or identical state laws related to food requirements. It also does not prevent states from enforcing laws on freshness dating, labeling, inspection, religious dietary requirements, or origin statements.
